1 set up

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
sns.set_style('white')

3 dplyr to pandas translation

  • dplyr –> pandas

  • mutate –> assign

  • select –> filter (the most confusing one)

  • rename –> rename

  • filter –> query

  • arrange –> sort_values

  • group_by –> groupby

  • summarize –> agg

4 piping in pandas

EXAMPLE 1:

Compare to dplyr

#| message: false
library(tidyverse)
diamonds %>% 
  select(carat, color) %>% 
  filter(color == 'E') %>% 
  head(3)
df.filter(['carat', 'color']).query('color == "E"').head(3)
carat color
0 0.23 E
1 0.21 E
2 0.23 E

OR, we can wrap it around parenthesis to go over the next line

(df
 .filter(['carat', 'color'])
 .query('color == "E"')
 .head(3))
carat color
0 0.23 E
1 0.21 E
2 0.23 E

EXAMPLE 2:

# dplyr
diamonds %>%
  select(starts_with('c')) %>%
  filter(cut %in% c('Ideal', 'Premium')) %>%
  group_by(cut, color, clarity) %>%
  summarize(avgcarat = mean(carat, na.rm=TRUE),
            n = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(avgcarat)) %>%
  head()

Lets write this in pandas.

(df.
    filter(regex='^c').
    query("cut in ['Ideal', 'Premium']").
    groupby(['cut', 'color', 'clarity']).
    agg(['mean', 'size']).
    sort_values(by = ('carat', 'mean'), ascending = False).
    head())
carat
mean size
cut color clarity
Ideal J I1 1.990000 2
Premium I I1 1.605833 24
J I1 1.578462 13
SI2 1.554534 161
Ideal H I1 1.475526 38

5 pivoting

  • tidyr —> pandas

  • gather/pivot_longer —> melt

  • spread/pivot_wider —> pivot
